complaint_summary: Abdul Ghafoor alleged that Nawab Din forcibly entered Khokha No. 33-A, obstructed his business, and claimed possession as a shareholder.
investigation_summary: Police report confirmed likelihood of breach of peace due to dispute over Khokha No. 33-A. City Magistrate ordered attachment under Section 146(1), Cr. P. C., and directed both parties to submit claims.
judgment_summary: The court quashed the Magistrate's order under Section 146(1), Cr. P. C., citing lack of jurisdiction due to Nawab Din's possession exceeding two months. Parties were advised to approach Civil Courts for ownership and rent disputes.
legal_arguments: Jurisdiction under Section 145(4), Cr. P. C., requires possession within two months prior to the order.
Attachment under Section 146(1), Cr. P. C., requires completion of inquiry under Section 145(4).
Magistrate exceeded scope of Section 145(4), Cr. P. C., by not determining possession before attachment.
key_issues: Jurisdiction under Section 145(4), Cr. P. C.
Attachment under Section 146(1), Cr. P. C.

legal_terms.custodia legis: Property under legal custody to maintain status quo.

words_and_phrases.breach of peace: Likelihood of disturbance due to dispute.

summary_vector_notes: Dispute over Khokha No. 33-A led to attachment order under Section 146(1), Cr. P. C., which was quashed due to lack of jurisdiction. Parties advised to approach Civil Courts for resolution.

section_145_crpc.subsection_4: Proviso restricts jurisdiction based on possession within two months before the order
key_points: Magistrate must decide possession without reference to merits or claims.
If dispossession occurred within two months, relief may be granted.

section_146_crpc.attachment_provision: Attachment requires completion of inquiry under section 145 and finding of possession.

legal_findings.jurisdiction_issue: Court lacked jurisdiction due to possession exceeding two months.
legal_findings.attachment_order_issue: Attachment order under section 146(1) was unjustified without inquiry under section 145.

recommendation.alternative_remedy: Parties advised to approach Civil Courts for ownership and rent disputes.

precedents_cited.case: Ch. Muhammad Siddiq v. Sahibzada Sahibyar Khan
precedents_cited.principle: Possession within two months required for proceedings under section 145.

precedents_cited.case: Debendra Chandra Sarkar v. Khodaram Sangma
precedents_cited.principle: Proviso to section 145(4) must be followed literally.
Magistrate cannot enter into title question in possession disputes.
Attachment under section 146 requires completion of inquiry under section 145.
